Amoeba.description: Amoeba is a shapeless, single-celled organism that moves using pseudopodia. It surrounds and engulfs food particles like bacteria using phagocytosis.
interactions: Competes with Paramecium for bacterial food
Can be prey for larger organisms like Hydra

Euglena.habitat: Stagnant freshwater rich in organic matter
Euglena.description: Euglena is a unique microorganism that shows both plant and animal traits. It has chloroplasts to perform photosynthesis and a flagellum to move around.
interactions: Competes with other microorganisms for light and nutrients
Can coexist with bacteria and algae

Hydra.habitat: Clean, still freshwater bodies like ponds and streams
Hydra.description: Hydra is a tiny freshwater predator with tentacles. It captures prey like Paramecium and Amoeba using stinging cells (nematocysts).
interactions: Plays a role in controlling population of smaller protists

Paramecium.habitat: Freshwater environments with decaying organic matter
Paramecium.description: Paramecium is a slipper-shaped microorganism that moves using cilia. It feeds on bacteria and small particles, digesting them in food vacuoles.
interactions: Competes with Amoeba for food sources

Rod_bacteria.description: Rod-shaped bacteria are common microorganisms that help break down organic matter. Some are beneficial, while others can cause disease.

Spherical_bacteria.description: Spherical bacteria may exist as single cells or in clusters. Some are harmless, while others are involved in infections.
interactions: Consumed by protists like Amoeba and Paramecium

Spiral_bacteria.description: These spiral-shaped bacteria move with flagella and thrive in aquatic habitats. Some are involved in nitrogen fixation.
interactions: Compete with other bacteria for nutrients

Yeast.description: Yeasts are single-celled fungi that reproduce by budding. They are used in baking and fermentation, and can sometimes colonize microscope slides.
interactions: Coexist with bacteria in nutrient-rich samples
